These people are absolutely being denied part of a full roster of common and safe medical services, paid for by their own work. The use of these medical services should be strictly between them, their doctor, and their God.

Suppose you were obese. Suppose you developed diabetes. Suppose I (a business owner) told you too bad, it was your own moral failing for drinking all those sodas and eating whole pizzas in one sitting, and we're not covering insulin and needles in our health insurance. You're not being denied anything! You can still purchase your own insulin and needles. Have fun, you louse.

Or suppose you had prostate cancer and got your prostate removed. Now you can't get an erection. You and your spouse are doomed to 25 years of no physical intimacy. Well, that's just a lifestyle choice you want to make. Too bad, not my problem. God clearly wanted it that way!

The point is that being an employer does not give me the wisdom, knowledge, or moral standing to make judgments about your medical care. It is patronizing and obnoxious for me to think that's my right or my business.

My friend Mike and I disagree on the electrification of the desert. I having been influenced by Edward Abby's "Desert Solitude," find the government give away of public lands to private interests to be bad policy. The "Green Groups" he refers to, is primarily the Sierra Club, who's members worked long and hard to get the Mojave National Monument created, which all of us can use for recreation.

The Sierra Club promotes distributed solar, which basically means putting solar on as many homes as possible. The San Diego School District now gets a high percentage of their power from solar on school property. In the are where I live, we get about 300 days a year of sun, and the rest of the time, some overcast, but only a few days with no sun.

Distributed solar, where individual producers can sell excess back to the power companies is a financial threat to them. PG&E is the most resistant producer fight all forms of solar, and wind power, where as SMUD (Sacramento Municipal Utility District) encourages it.

Mike has written a very well referenced study on building solar plants in the Mojave, but we in the Sierra Club think distributed solar will work just as well.

Dr. K,

One additional point about the fundamental importance of efficient transportation to the economy. The evidence shows that transportation efficiency is also fundamental to our national security. President Eisenhower understood this in his Defense Highway Initiative. He had seen the autobahns of Europe and knew what efficiency meant. He did not hesitate to give defense top priority.

I know that Navy Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said during the great deficit fights in Congress in 2011 that "Debt is the biggest threat to U.S. national security," I really don't think he meant that, as a Navy Officer, I am certain what he meant to say is the slowed economy & the debt it has created is the biggest threat to National Security. All senior Navy officers know that a weak, slow growing economy weakens our global defense & homeland security capabilities.

In fact, the principal economic raison d'etre of the Navy is to keep our Sea Lines of Communications open.

We also have serious and growing domestic requirements for foul weather evacuation in from our coastal areas, etc. Our highways and railways are not ready as a Nation for efficient evacuations.

Therefore, I recommend including a large portion the U.S. transport infrastructure in the Defense and Homeland Defense Budgets. The GOP and Democratic leadership understand the importance of this mission.

Dr. K,

You are correct. The forces of darkness are creating another "fiscal cliff" crisis. It is not an accident, it is deliberate & it promises to pay off big for the GOP.

It is frustrating, because I know that transportation of goods & food is fundamental to the US economy. The more efficient the transportation, the more economic growth with the same resources. Our aging, pothole ridden, congested highways have taken a huge toll on the economy. As you point out spending has been severely scaled back and the Trust Fund has been in trouble for decades.

18.4 cents per gallon is obviously too low to keep pace with the requirements of our system. We have know this for some time but no one seems to have the guts to take care of this simple policy change. Per gallon is bad policy, it would be better if the user fee were based on the purchase price of fuel. The incentives would be in the public interest.

What is being missed by our policymakers, including the GOP constituency, is the opportunity cost of failing to make our logistics more efficient. At current interest rates, investment in our highways, bridges, & tunnels would pay for themselves in greater economic growth.

I urge giving attention increasing transport efficiency & investing in R&D for better structural material, concrete, etc. The 300 mph Maglev truck hauling system at 10 cents per ton mile makes sense. It can make rich Americans richer and the benefits can be broadly shared with all Americans.

Reading comprehension fail. This case is not about a constitutional right to have your contraceptives covered. Nor is it about requiring an employer to purchase something.
The employer objecting to sending the insurance company a form that says that "we are a religious institution and object to paying for contraception" (I am paraphrasing). Receipt of that form triggers the insurance company to cover contraception themselves (with no contribution from the employer) which insurance is happy to do because, guess what - it is much cheaper to pay for contraception than for pregnancies. So the employer is objecting to SENDING A FORM. That is it. Presumably because sending such a form would then allow their employees to access covered contraception rather than having to pay for it out of pocket (to the tune of several hundred $ per month) on top of their premiums.

Still in the 1970's are we? Fast forward to today. Government mandates that insurance coverage for 20 forms of contraception must be provided free to women. Two are found to violate religious beliefs.

Same old claims about uppity men, keep women in their place, etc.

It's not the laws that have remained stuck in the past. It's the reaction to anything that touches, no matter how slightly, contraception.

This isn't a male/female divide; it's about 5 Roman Catholics who are evidently unable to separate their duties as Supreme Court justices from the teachings of the Roman Catholic church in which they were brought up.
AACNY - Take a break from parroting right wing talking points and look up the definition of insurance.

And leave the "big decisions" for  the males.  Who, of course, know what is best for females.   When are American women voters going to wake up and take back control of their lives?

I'm a psychologist, not an economist. When my people try to explain why someone (or a political party) is doing something, the last thing we do is listen to what they say. A rational person looks for consistency in behavior and infers motives. Some guy named Freud figured this out over a century ago, and it has worked pretty well since.
In looking at the behavior of the Republican Party there can be little doubt that the motivation behind their post 2008 concern with the deficit is an intentional plan to sabotage an economic recovery. It certainly can't be an actual concern for the national debt since they also intentionally ran up most of that. They will run in the next two election on the failure of President Obama to fix the economy.
The great mistake of President Obama and the Democratic Party is that they have not called Republicans on their obvious attempts to work against economic recovery. Just two days ago, President Obama was talking about the obstructionist tactics of House Republicans as a difference of opinion with people who loved their country. That has been an unreasonable assumption since 2008.
The irony is that without Republican machinations--two debt crises, one shut down, cuts in federal spending, and now blocking highway funds--the deficit would be much lower than it is today because of the much faster recovery of the economy.
Aah! But such a nuanced and more accurate understanding of a concept does not lend itself to screaming catchy eye-popping news!

Thanks for that link. It is interesting to read how the study's authors, Phoebe Clarke and Ian Ayres, have a bit of a different take-away than David Brooks. Here is their conclusion:

"In conclusion, our results appear to paint a picture of heightened individuality—a picture that, despite the social nature of high school athletics, should not be wholly unexpected. Although sports, including ones in which students compete individually, are organized around teams, athletic competitions create forums for individual success. It was Brandi Chastain, for example, and not her team, who scored the winning penalty kick in 1999. In fact, Chastain’s reaction provides anecdotal evidence in support of the individual development approach and against the societal one. Rather than running to her team and hugging them in excitement, Chastain’s first move was to drop to the grass, alone, and savor her individual victory. Her reactions is also consistent with our results: in defiance of traditional gender norms and societal expectations, Brandi Chastain took off her shirt, and, to the shock of many, exposed her bra to the world."

My takeaway of this study--high school girls that participate in competitive sports are more likely to act as they please, rather than as David Brooks would like them to act.

Read the Clarke & Ayres article for yourself here: (PDF)
http://islandia.law.yale.edu/ayers/12.6%20Chastain%20Effect%20with%20vis...

Their meaning of single mother is: "woman has had a child and is currently divorced, separated, or has never been married". (widowed is counted with the non-single mothers).

One of their footnotes says: Readers should be careful in interpreting the “Single Mother” variable. A “Single Mother” is not necessarily raising her child(ren) alone. Her children could be living with her husband or grandparents. She might be living with her children’s father but not married to him. Or she could be living with a new boyfriend who has adopted the children as his own.

Re: "One policy I believe most Independents would go for is campaign finance reform with teeth"

Unless one of the Republican justices dies or retires, we can't have that without a constitutional amendment.

If Americans choose to vote for corrupt party candidates, they should be allowed to continue to make that choice.  Tyranny in government begins with taking away choices because people are making bad choices.

The only thing most Independents can probably agree on is that neither party represents their views or has the ideas the voter thinks will help this country.

One policy I believe most Independents would go for is campaign finance reform with teeth and possibly financial reform (we have seen little evidence that the laws passed in the aftermath of the Great Recession have helped -- in fact subprime mortgages are being sold again and derivatives are still largely unregulated). Those are two big areas of agreement.

Another might be a campaign that is NOT re-hashing the same social issues. I'm afraid the two major parties like the constant posturing on social issues. It doesn't take much imagination to plot a campaign of those. It does to offer ideas to tackle our real problems before we become the third-world country we're on our way to becoming.

Public-private partnerships offer some terrific innovations and can entice pension, insurance and private equity capital into infrastructure finance.  I support P3s.  It should be noted, though, that the required returns are high: generally mid-teens to upper teens.  It would be helpful to pair the private capital with public funds, to reduce the financing costs, while retaining the P3 efficiencies relating to design, construction, maintenance and life-cycle costing.

The very wealthy aren't very often loaning capital to help friends and neighbors open dry cleaning stores. See the GINI coefficient.So good wages are good for America. They are however likely to keep the U.S. falling behind in bandwidth access/quality viz. the rest of the world while paying higher prices, like, say, healthcare.
